document.docTitle: A revision of the genus Coryssiphus Simon, 1903, with its transfer to Systariinae (Araneae: Miturgidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the genus Coryssiphus Simon, 1903, with its transfer to Systariinae (Araneae: Miturgidae)

emphasis.docTitle:
A revision of the genus
Coryssiphus Simon, 1903
, with its transfer to Systariinae ( Araneae : Miturgidae )

paragraph.emphasis: Royal Museum for Central Africa, B 3080 Tervuren, Belgium

subSection.paragraph: Ễ dochterland@telenet.be; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8306-3554

The genus
Coryssiphus Simon, 1903
is redescribed and found to be composed of two species.
Coryssiphus unicolor Simon, 1903
is synonymised with
C. cinerascens Simon, 1903
, being the female of that species.
Coryssiphus praeustus Simon, 1903
and
C. cinerascens
are redescribed and the genus is transferred from Liocranidae to Miturgidae : Systariinae based on a number of somatic and genitalic characters. The peculiar presence of
Coryssiphus
in Africa is briefly discussed.

Key words:
Arachnida
,
Liocranidae
,
Cape Peninsula
, spider , taxonomy

The genus
Coryssiphus Simon, 1903
was described by Simon (1903a) from the South African Cape Peninsula (“ Prom. Bonae Spei! ”). The genus was originally considered by Simon to be close to
Mesiotelus Simon, 1897
and
Scotina Menge, 1873
( Simon 1903a ). Simon had two males and one female at his disposal, which he attributed to three different species. The larger male was described as
Coryssiphus praeusta Simon, 1903
, soon thereafter corrected to
C. praeustus ( Simon 1903b )
, since the gender of
Coryssiphus
is masculine and
praeustus
(meaning burnt, coloured as charred wood) is an adjective. The smaller male,
C. cinerascens Simon, 1903
was considered to differ from
C. praeustus
by its size and by the presence of six instead of seven ventral spine pairs on tibiae I and II ( Fig. 1A, B ). The single female, possessing 6–7 prolateral and retrolateral ventral spines on tibiae I and II, as well as an epigyne with median, anteriorly converging dark ridges, was described as
C. unicolor Simon, 1903
( Fig. 8A, B, E ). In that same year (1903b), Simon placed
Coryssiphus
in his concept of Clubionidae : Liocraninae and designated
C. praeustus
as the type species. Roewer (1954) also listed the genus in Clubionidae : Liocraninae.

Lehtinen (1967) raised Liocraninae to family rank within what he delimited as Amaurobioidea. However, Lehtinen (1967) , who erroneously attributed the type species designation to Petrunkevitch (1928) , commented on
Coryssiphus
: “Transferred here outside Amaurobioidea, but its position remains unknown”. Nevertheless, all subsequent literature has classified
Coryssiphus
in Liocranidae , a family that belongs within Amaurobioidea. Brignoli (1983) listed the genus in Liocranidae incertae sedis , based on “some rather vague remarks” by Lehtinen (1967) . Because there is no subsequent work on
Coryssiphus , Platnick (1989)
also listed the genus in Liocranidae , where it has resided to the present day ( WSC 2023 ).

The examination of Simon’s types in the present study shows that
Coryssiphus
is not a liocranid, but belongs to Miturgidae : Systariinae, as defined in Deeleman-Reinhold (2001: 201) . The genus shares many characteristics with
Systaria Simon, 1897
. Moreover, additional specimens from the collections in MRAC, NCA and NMSA allowed the deduction that
C. unicolor
is conspecific with
C. cinerascens
, reducing the number of species in this enigmatic genus to two.

Specimens were observed, photographed and drawn using Euromex MIC465 and Olympus SZX9 binocular microscopes. Tarsal claws and vulvae (cleared in methyl salicylate) were observed, photographed and drawn using a Wild M12 compound microscope. Stereomicroscope photographs were also made with Praktica DC42 or Sony NEX-5 digital cameras and, in case of multiple focus photographs, the image series obtained was stacked with Zerene Stacker version 1.04 build T 2023-06-11 -1120. Stacking photographs of the habitus of the type specimens were taken with a DFC500 camera mounted on a Leica MZ16 and piloted with the Leica Application Suite (LAS) stacking software (ver. 4.13; Leica, https://leicacamera.com), with a Z-stack of 15–20 images merged into a single photomontage. The colour drawing of the male of
C. praeustus
was rendered with an Aerograph Devilbiss Super 63 E airbrush.

Abbreviations used: AER, anterior eye row; ALE, anterior lateral eyes; ALS, anterior lateral spinnerets; AME, anterior median eyes; C, conductor; CO, copulatory openings; cy, cymbium; di, diameter; do, dorsal; E, embolus; fe, femur; fr, frontal; ICS, intercoxal sclerites—intercoxal sclerites are six small triangular or elongated sclerites surrounding the sternum, their tips penetrating between the coxae of the legs—they may be free, or fused with the sternum ( Bosselaers & Jocqué 2002 : fig. 1K); ID, insemination duct; lat, lateral; LOP, lorum pediculi —the lorum is a longitudinal sclerite covering the dorsal side of the petiolus—it may be single or composed of two consecutive or juxtaposed sclerites separated by a membrane ( Simon 1892 : figs 9–14); MA, median apophysis; MOQ, median ocular quadrangle; mt, metatarsus; pa, patella; PCT, precoxal triangles—precoxal triangles are small triangular sclerites surrounding the sternum, their tips facing the bases of the coxae ( Penniman 1985 )—they may be free, or fused with the sternum ( Bosselaers & Jocqué 2002 : fig. 1K); PER, posterior eye row; pl, prolateral; PLB, pleural bars—pleural bars are narrow, horizontal sclerites between coxae and carapace, one above each coxa (“pièces épimériennes” of Simon 1892 : fig. 29)—they may be fused among each other ( Bosselaers & Jocqué 2002 : fig. 1P), with the intercoxal sclerites, and/or with the carapace; pl, prolateral; PLE, posterior lateral eyes; PLS, posterior lateral spinnerets; PME, posterior median eyes; PMS, posterior median spinnerets; PSP, plagula sternalis postica — the plagula is a triangular or ribbon-shaped sclerite situated on the ventral side of the petiolus—it may be fused with the sternum ( Simon 1892 : figs 15–18; Ledoux & Canard 1991 : figs 13,14); RH, retrocoxal hymen—the retrocoxal hymen is a weak spot, in most cases hyaline and lens- to dome-shaped, on the retrolateral face of coxa I ( Raven 1998 ; Bosselaers & Jocqué 2002 ); rl, retrolateral; RTA, retrolateral tibial apophysis; Sss, sickle-shaped sclerite— sclerotised structures accompanying spermatheca 1 ( Bosselaers & Jocqué 2022 ); ST1, spermatheca 1 (spermatheca connected to FD); ST2, spermatheca 2, an additional, mostly sclerotised hollow receptacle, presumably used for sperm storage (von Engelhardt 1910 ; Deeleman-Reinhold 2001 : “bursae”); ta, tarsus; ti, tibia; ve, ventral; vsp, ventral spine pairs; vts, ventral terminal spine; w, width.
Abbreviations of institutional collections (curators in parentheses):
CAS , California Academy of Sciences, San Francisco (N. Penny)
MNHN , Museum Nationale d’Histoire Naturelle de Paris (C. Rollard)
NCA , National Collection of Arachnida, Pretoria (P. Marais)
NMBA , National Museum, Bloemfontein (T. Peyper)
NMSA , KwaZulu-Natal Museum, Pietermaritzburg (M. Ziganira)
RMCA , Royal Museum for Central Africa, Tervuren (D. Van den Spiegel)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species:
Coryssiphus praeustus Simon, 1903
, by subsequent designation ( Simon 1903b )

Diagnosis.
Coryssiphus
is vaguely similar to
Arabelia Bosselaers, 2009
and
Drassinella Banks, 1904
by the absence of C, MA and other tegular apophyses in the male palp ( Fig. 4A, B ). For the same reason, it differs from all other Liocranidae . Moreover, it differs from
Liocranum L. Koch, 1866
,
Mesiotelus Simon, 1897
and
Hesperocranum Ubick & Platnick, 1991
by the parallel tapeta in the PME ( Fig. 3D ) and the absence of ventrolateral erectile bristles on the anterior legs ( Ubick & Platnick 1991 ).
Coryssiphus
differs from
Arabelia
and
Drassinella
by the shape of the male palpal bulbus, which is circular in ventral view instead of oval, by the long and basally inserted embolus, and by the short and simple ID. It differs from
Systaria Simon, 1897
( Miturgidae : Systariinae) by the somewhat smaller AME, stronger vsp on ti and mt I and II, trochanters that are only weakly notched, and a vulva with anterior CO ( Fig. 6A, E ).

heading.emphasis:
Key to the species of
Coryssiphus

paragraph.keyLead:
- Total l 3–4 mm , ti I vsp 6, bulbus diameter 50% of cymbium l, ti I l/w 7–8, palpal ti l / sternum l 0.5–0.6.................................................................................................
Coryssiphus cinerascens

3 Total l 5–7, central depression of epigyne bell-shaped, longitudinal sclerotised rims only diverging in posterior third, long axis of ST2 antero-posterior...............................................................
Coryssiphus praeustus

- Total l 4–5, central depression of epigyne trapezoidal, longitudinal sclerotised rims diverging over entire length, long axis of ST2 antero-lateral..................................................................
Coryssiphus cinerascens

;

.

SOUTH AFRICA :
Western Cape
: 1♂ , Cape Town , Kirstenbosch National Botanical Gardens , 33°59.216’S , 18°25.742’E ,
165 m a.s.l.
, sifting litter, Afromontane forest ,
4 October 2022
, leg. C. Haddad , D. Harms , R. Booysen & J. Neethling ( NMBA 18841 )
;
2♀ , Cape Town , Table Mountain , Orange Kloof Nature Reserve , 34°00’00’’, 18°23’42’’E,
125 m a.s.l.
, sifting leaf litter, mould and rotten wood in Afromontane forest ,

, leg. B.L. Fisher ( CAS 9033202 );
1♀ , Table Mountain National Park , Orange Kloof , “site 21”, leaf litter in Afrotemperate forest ,
18 November 2008
, leg. C. Uys ( NCA 2011 /886)
.

Diagnosis.
Coryssiphus praeustus
is close to
C. cinerascens
but differs from it by the larger body size, the more slender and longer legs, especially the tibiae of the legs and palps ( Tables 1 , 2 ), the more elongate cymbium of the male palp, the epigyne which has a bell-shaped instead of trapezoidal central depression ( Figs 4C , 6B , 7C ) and the ST2 which are oriented longitudinally instead of antero-laterally ( Figs 6A , 7E ).

Description. Male ( holotype unless mentioned otherwise). Somatic morphology as described for the genus. Total l (n = 2) 5.3; carapace l 2.5, w 1.9 ; sternum l 1.4, w 1.2 . Fovea situated 1.8 from front, fovea l 0.3 ( Fig. 5A ). Eye arrangement: AER w 0.60 , PER w 0.76 , MOQ frontal end 0.30, posterior end 0.37, longitudinal l 0.39. Legs long and thin ( Table 1 ). Leg spination as in Fig. 2A ; ventral side of ti I with 7 vsp, ti II with 6 vsp. Male palp with slender ti and cymbium more than twice as long as diameter of bulbus ( Table 2 , Figs 3C , 4A, B ).
fe pa ti mt ta Total

Female (RMCA 131898, unless otherwise mentioned). Somatic morphology as described for the genus. Total l 5.6–6.8 (n = 5), carapace l 2.4, w 2.0 ; sternum l 1.2, w 1.2 . Fovea situated 1.4 from front, fovea l 0.4 ( Fig. 7A ). Eye arrangement: AER w 0.55 , PER w 0.68 , MOQ frontal end 0.29, posterior end 0.34, longitudinal l 0.32. Legs long and thin ( Table 1 ). Leg spination as in Fig. 2C, D ; ventral side of ti I with 7 vsp, ti II with 6 vsp. Epigyne with bell-shaped central depression and sclerotised lateral rims that diverge in posterior third ( Figs 4C , 6B , 7C ). Long axis of ST2 oriented in longitudinal (antero-posterior) direction ( Figs 6A , 7E ).
fe pa ti mt ta Total
Distribution. At present only known from the South African Cape Peninsula, but most probably present within a radius of at least 60 km from the latter (C.R. Haddad, pers. comm.).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Coryssiphus cinerascens
is close to
C. praeustus
, but differs from it by the smaller body size, the slightly shorter, sturdier legs, especially the tibiae of legs and palps ( Tables 1 , 2 ), the shorter cymbium of the male palp ( Figs 5C, D , 6D ), the epigyne that has a trapezoidal instead of bell-shaped central depression ( Figs 6C , 8E ), and the ST2 that are oriented antero-laterally instead of almost longitudinally ( Figs 6E , 8G ).

Description. Male ( holotype unless mentioned otherwise). Somatic morphology as described for the genus. Total l (n = 3) 3.2–3.3; carapace l 1.6, w 1.3 ; sternum l 0.9, w 0.9 . Fovea situated 1.1 from front, fovea l 0.3 ( Fig. 5A ). Eye arrangement: AER w 0.34 , PER w 0.47 , MOQ frontal end 0.20, posterior end 0.26, longitudinal l 0.24. Legs relatively short and sturdy ( Table 1 ). Leg spination as in Fig. 2E ; ventral side of ti I with 6 vsp, ti II with 5 vsp. Male palp with cylindrical ti, cy about twice as long as diameter of bulbus ( Table 2 , Figs 5C , 6D ).
fe pa ti mt ta Total

Female ( holotype of
C. unicolor
unless otherwise stated). Somatic morphology as described for the genus. Total l 4.7–5.2 (n = 3), carapace l 1.7, w 1.5 ; sternum l 1.0, w 0.9 . Fovea situated 1.1 from front, fovea l 0.3 ( Fig. 8A ). Eye arrangement: AER w 0.45 , PER w 0.55 , MOQ frontal end 0.21, posterior end 0.28, longitudinal l 0.26. Legs relatively short and sturdy ( Table 1 ). Leg spination as in Fig. 2F, G ; ventral side of ti I with 6–7 vsp, ti II with 6 vsp. Epigyne with trapezoidal central depression and sclerotised lateral rims that diverge over their entire length ( Figs 6C , 8E ). Long axis of ST2 oriented in antero-lateral direction ( Figs 6E , 8G ).
fe pa ti mt ta Total
Distribution. At present only known from the Cape Peninsula and Stellenbosch, South Africa , but most probably present within a radius of at least 60 km from the latter (Haddad, pers. comm.).

subSection.paragraph:
Study of the available specimens shows that the genus
Coryssiphus
encompasses two species with a discrete size range ( Table 1 ) and subtle but clear differences in the genitalia. The larger species,
C. praeustus
, has longer, more slender front legs, a considerably longer and more slender male palpal tibia ( Figs 3C , 4A, B ), a longer cymbium relative to the bulbus ( Tables 1 , 2 ), an epigyne with a bell-shaped instead of trapezoidal central depression ( Figs 4C , 6B , 7C ), and ST2 that are oriented longitudinally instead of antero-laterally, as in
C. cinerascens
( Figs 6A , 7E ). The female of
C. praeustus
is described here for the first time. Simon’s small-sized
C. unicolor
turns out to be the female of
C. cinerascens
.

The taxonomic affinity of
Coryssiphus
is problematic. First of all, Liocranidae , the family in which the genus is presently placed, is poorly defined ( Jocqué & Dippenaar-Schoeman 2006 ), since not a single synapomorphy has been found for it so far ( Bosselaers 2009 ). Moreover, recent work suggests that Liocranidae , as currently composed, may not be monophyletic (
Azevedo et al. 2022
;
Fernández et al . 2018
;
Kulkarni et al. 2023
; Ramírez 2014 , Wheeler et al . 2016). At least, Liocranidae seems to be divided into a group centred around
Liocranum L. Koch, 1866
, whose members have an oblique median tapetum ( Ramírez 2014 ) and obliquely depressed endites (
Chu et al . 2023
, figs 8, 10; Ramírez 2014 ; Ubick & Platnick 1991 ), and a group centred around
Agroeca Westring, 1861
, whose members lack these features ( Bosselaers & Jocqué 2013 , Domènech et al . in press).
Coryssiphus
differs strongly from the
Liocranum
-group by the absence of an oblique tapetum in the PME ( Fig. 3D ), the absence of ventrolateral erectile bristles on the anterior legs, and the absence of an oblique depression and lateral notch of the endites. It also differs from the
Agroeca
-group by its simple circular bulbus without C, MA or additional tegular apophyses. In contrast,
Coryssiphus
has non-depressed endites with a marked thin, diagonal groove ( Fig. 3F ), as in
Xantharia Deeleman-Reinhold, 2001
( Deeleman-Reinhold 2001 : fig. 258), AME slightly larger than ALE, ALS separated, relatively large PLS with a long, conical apical segment, a simple subcircular bulbus with a long, sickle-shaped basally implanted E, a hook-shaped RTA (although rarely bifid or inconspicuous in some Systariinae), and a vulva with short ID, all characters that are found in Miturgidae : Systariinae, as defined in Deeleman-Reinhold (2001: 201-222) . The similarity between the male palps of
Coryssiphus
and
Systaria elberti (Strand, 1913)
for example, is striking ( Deeleman-Reinhold 2001 : fig. 239; Jäger 2018 ).
Coryssiphus
is herewith tentatively transferred to Miturgidae : Systariinae, as presently constituted ( WSC 2023 ).

It must be admitted that the affinities and composition of Systariinae are still debated (
Chu et al . 2023
; Jäger 2018 ). The occurrence of Systariinae in Africa is puzzling, as the subfamily was only known from Southeast Asia prior to this study ( Deeleman-Reinhold 2001 ; WSC 2023 ). However, comparable disjunct distributions have been observed in other taxa. The eleven species in the spider genus
Medmassa Simon, 1887
are all known from Southeast Asia and Australia , except
M. semiaurantiaca Simon, 1909
, which is only known from scattered locations spread over Africa ( Haddad & Bosselaers 2010 ). In the jumping spider genus
Depreissia Lessert, 1942
, the type species,
D. myrmex Lessert, 1942
, is only known from Congo , while the only other species in the genus,
D. decipiens Deeleman-Reinhold & Floren, 2003
is only known from Borneo. The zodariid
Tropizodium peregrinum Jocqué & Churchill, 2005
has an extremely disjunct distribution, only being known from Australia and Réunion Island (
Jacquot et al . 2016
).
Vytfutia Deeleman-Reinhold, 1986
includes three species from Southeast Asia, whereas the fourth species,
V. halandrefana Griswold, 2022
, lives in Madagascar . Griswold (2022) hypothesized that this species may have reached Madagascar by “island hopping” from Southeast Asia to Madagascar . Andriamalala (2007) proposed a similar mechanism to explain the presence of the salticid genus
Padilla Peckham & Peckham, 1894
in Madagascar .

A number of cases lend support to this hypothesis.
Jacquot et al . (2016)
mention the presence of the Southeast Asian
Palicanus caudatus Thorell, 1897
, also a systariine, and
Orthobula impressa Simon, 1897
( Trachelidae ) on the Seychelles and Réunion , islands located in an intermediate position between Southeast Asia and Africa. The Calicnemiinae ( Odonata : Platycnemididae ) are represented by the vast majority of their genera in Southeast Asia, but five genera have at least one representative in the Seychelles , Madagascar or mainland Africa ( Gassmann 2005 ).

The collection curators mentioned above are gratefully acknowledged for providing the specimens used in this research. Rudy Jocqué is also thanked for invaluable help in locating the RMCA specimens and for taking the habitus photographs of the
Coryssiphus
holotypes . Special thanks are due to Martín Ramirez for being the first person to draw the author’s attention to the fact that
Coryssiphus
belongs in Systariinae, an attribution confirmed by Christa Deeleman-Reinhold in discussions. The author is very much indebted to Christa too, for long and interesting exchanges of information over a delicious bowl of soup. Norman Platnick is thanked for fruitful discussions on the genus. The author is especially grateful to Charles Haddad for continued support and advice and for freely providing good photographs and additional information on
Coryssiphus
specimens from South Africa . Thanks are also due to the referees, Ansie Dippenaar-Schoeman and Arnaud Henrard, who provided useful comments helping to improve the manuscript.

.
